title: The View from Castle Rock
author: Alice Munro
review:
[[2024-11-12]]

halfway through my read of this the allegations about munros indifference to her husbands molestations came out, and i already hadn’t liked it. the first half of the book, ostensibly based on her family history, feels like little more than an example of one of many upper middle class white people in the americas sudden late in life obsessions with ancestry, as though such a thing might absolve their guilt of being settlers via a sort of tightly focused counter-history, the only difference in munros case being her literary talent and (perhaps more relevantly, given the low quality of many stories in this book) renown, the only reason one might otherwise give this book attention

this is a book from canada, the land of the unmarked grave and the missing child. this is a near memoir of alice munro, most famous this year at least (2024) for choosing to abandon her child to keep up the status quo. this is not a moral condemnation (the world has fallen and will keep falling for all time), but given that this book aims at something close to looking at the facts of this world, the lack of engagement with these themes comes off as shallow as all hell, as well as boring

however: this book is old. these themes, when it was published, were better suppressed. you can’t entirely blame it for what it is. perhaps it’s better to say it’s something that aged into irrelevance all at once. it was written for a world we no longer live in

title: The Secret to Superhuman Strength
author: Alison Bechdel
review:
[[2024-08-18]]

Is there a term for wanting to love something so bad you don't really like it? The first section of this, the intro, is so wonderful, so fun, so much of a newspaper comic, that its hard not to feel disappointed with how it immediately feels like an attempt to recreate the shape of her last two near-perfect books, just without what makes them work. The art is wonderful though. Maybe its cause the pages of my copy are just to large, but they feel wonderfully full.

title: Ice
author: Anna Kavan
content:
# rev
[[2024-10-21]]

nothings more damning for an author, imo, than to be compared to kafka. like air or sand can alter its shape to fit anything that can hold it, kafka is a thousand things at
once. any fiction influenced by him it’s maybe a hundred of those things at best, and every reader hopes to find a different hundred

what i’m saying is the way i was introduced to this, as a sort of obsessive or more strung out franz kafka, really harmed how i read the work. cause it’s really good! a sort of lightish sci-fi nightmare, as obsessive as described and almost impossible to hold down. ever detail, so it seems, changes the moment it’s realized, which only makes our terrible narrator’s obsession feel more real: what he wants is a control beyond the possible, solidity only imaginable in a frozen world

title: Complete Stories
author: Anton Chekov
review:
## vol 1
Dude could write. No other way to say it. Enjoyable to the page (or,
in my case, audio file). Worth noting that our boy is both the
"literary" icon the modern MFA exalts him as /and/ something more,
without contradiction. His goals and styles may be similar to lit
fic, in other words, but he's got a very different worldview. His
stuff is very clipped, stark, and ultimately humorous, despite the
grimness of it. It allows an incomplete knowledge of human behavior,
despite its ultimately social, realist bent. No wonder lesser attempts
at his styles are so drawn to it

title: Rendezvous with Rama
author: Arthur C. Clarke
content: - [[2025-03-25]]: defo has that “poetic” quality I ascribe to [[Cixin Liu]]
review:
[[2025-04-03]]

I cannot be objective. The exact quality of contradiction that makes up a Arthur C Clarke (god and science, poetry and dullness, absolute faith in the persistence of a gentlemanly sort of bureaucratic benevolence already betrayed in open decades before he wrote) charms me to no end. Perhaps it’s a perspective alien to my own, thus interesting. Maybe it’s the opposite: an optimism I’ve (half a century later) outgrown. But I adored this novel. What if HP Lovecraft followed nightmares with deep interest. What if there was beauty in the mystery unsolved?
whyRead: - a [[Ross's Game Dungeon]] vid about a game based on it made me interested

title: Negative Space
author: B R Yeager
review:
[[2024-09-05]]

read this one tryna see what some of the more popular books of its genre are like, what might you call its genre, extreme horror perhaps? while i cant exactly say i liked it, i did finish it, which is more than i can say for a lot of other books i dont like, which i usually give up on at once, lol. im pretty fickle

i guess my major disappointment was that i expected something a little more extreme, or something more honestly nihilistic. and while there was gore, i feel it made the most basic mistake of gore in prose: you aint gotta see it. as a reader, you can choose (i mean, if you read like me) not to picture the gore. hell, if you're not like me you can just skip past it. so for gore to be really effective in fiction, you need to _care_ about what's happening, you feel me? so in combination with the books intentionally flat, unconcerned characters, it falls real flat. a character cuts himself, lets say, but we've already established he doesn't care. we don't see his pain, so its like it isnt there at all. same idea with the sort of empty nihilism: it isnt there, it isnt felt, it doesnt happen

i guess im decrying the conservatism of it. while less declamatory, say, than like go ask alice or other satanic panic style books, the sex and drugs and violence in this (lets call it, for my own fun, the protestant bacchanalia) serve to titillate its reader a distance, a real transference thing, psychology whatever: like nothing in it can really be intense because to allow so much reality in might destroy the fantasy of it, like baby, what if pain was great

lot a words to say: oh well, it aint for me

title: Last Days
author: Brian Evenson
review:
[[2025-04-09]]

two novellas, one a bunch of fun, one too literary for its own good 

the first novella is maybe the closest i've read to American Kafka, not just for its circularity and absurdity being like Kafka's, but for how it adapts those ideas to America (note that lack of a k): religious obviously, violent obviously, but also supremely indifferent. let everything suffer, the American K says (note that even the character's name is Kline. Evenson's doing the riff on purpose); i just wanna go home. it'd be an absolute amazing riff if only it stuck the ending, if only it weren't a violent near-victory but instead a defeat as absolute as it is sudden

but then we wouldn't have the second novella, which is _significantly_ worse. it feels like a pale imitation of the first, the more common version of American attempts at Kafka: religious cults without identity, sudden violence, less absurd than so much unpleasant. and, worse, the plot is thin, or really not so much _thin_ (the first's is _much_ thinner, essentially just an excuse to layer images) as irrelevant, a sort of late season 2 twin peaks applying incident to incident in hopes that something sticks.

i really like the first novella tho
whyRead: - like his books, the covers connect

title: Suttree
author: Cormac McCarthy
review:
[[2024-06-27]]

how do reflect on a book you don't like. feels stupid and empty, maybe, to just say it didn't hit you, but to go into detail is just to like... i don't know, act like there's some depth to your dislike, as though you've thought through an opinion

let's be short: to me, this book is sweaty. this book is dull. (spoiler ahead, if ya care:) when, near the end, we get a hallucination scene, all i can imagine is Cormac McCarthy himself, in his mythic cabin, totally missing everything that made the hallucination section of Ulysses it cribs fun. all i can see when i read it is cormac mccarthy, sweaty. his family is wealthy, they can buy him air conditioning. but he, instead, would prefer himself an individual. his is not aware his ability to do so is, in part, because his wealth

what i really mean in that little jokey thing above is just to say i'm not a fan of much american existentialism. walker percy's the total opposite of cool. its as though every little american boy who dreams of writing it big has misread Simone de Beauvoir and decided, in their forgivably adolescent immaturity, that they truly are ex nihilo, they truly are free because they chose so, and thus by mistake (plz, forgive me, this part really depends on you having read The Ethics of Ambiguity, which you really ought to) become adventurers instead, only claiming, to extend their nihilist acts, to have existentialism at their base

yeah, so in short there was never any real chance i'd like this, lol

title: White Noise
author: Don Delilo
review:
[[2025-12-14]]

50% one of the best books I've read in a while, 50% more of the exact same, but someone boring

the whole first half astounded me. quick, absurd, and actually funny. its fun to have a self-awarely satirical character, aware of what's being left out. then, the airborne toxic event, and its even better: everythings shifted and muddled, everything's more unclear, are we getting some actual deadly seriousness, is this seriousness a comedy as well, is there any difference? it's a truly astounding balancing act, and i love it

then it just keeps going, becoming the basic satire it previously surpassed. i dont know why. it made me sad

title: The Wretched of the Earth
author: Frantz Fanon
content:
# rev
[[2024-10-27]]

just finished yesterday and.... tbh... i'm really unsure how i feel about it. Fanon is _by far_ a prose guy: every sentence, it seems now, was a delight, and i'm very much the kind to feel a good sentence equivalent to a good point. further, the book is SO of its time, in the sense that it's commenting on a certain historical phase as its happening, spotting patterns as they emerge. and his calls seem pretty right! the kitschification of national literature, for example, really stands out, to the point i have to wonder at the anger he'd feel towards tourism now, which (from what i gather with my light knowledge of the caribbean) feel like a real extension of that

this is a book that'll stay in my mind a long time, no matter what, each point i remember interacting with the experience of my life. i do, after all, work in what you might call a post-colonial industry. the things he speaks on then have developed into my life now

title: Amerika
author: Franz Kafka
review:
[[2024-11-02]]

man, what cam you say about a kafka novel? they’re so unfinished. each one starts so strong and with such purpose, then the action seems intent on drawing out, elaborating, confusing, contemplating while ignoring, dilly-dallying, so on. with his other two, eventually, past a couple fragments, they suddenly end. only this one doesn’t. suddenly (and hilariously), oklahoma. it seems like it might just drone on again

am i complaining? i don’t know! that’s some of the deal of this. it feels likebeing trapped inside a long, repeating spiral, no progress to be found, and yet its all hilarious as well. our main man karl’s an idiot. the worlds so frightening you have to laugh, or so absurdly silly you just wanna run and hide. it’s proto anime even, and not only for being a similarly weird kind of adolescent horny. and it keeps going. no wonder half his imitators write books in single sentences. that’s how it feels. its on and on and on and on and on

title: Liberation Day
author: George Saunders
review:
[[2025-11-29]]

a hundred different facets color every bit of life. i have two degrees in creative writing, therefore am of the system, but as anyone in any system knows, there’s no homogeneity, everybody is an edge. what i mean to say is i struggled with understanding the whole mfa deal, is it an artists colony, a credentials system? i’m perhaps too headstrong still in opinions of art (eg my belief the Christmas Story movies an act of evil). it shouldn’t be there for social reproduction (i still think that, though i know that’s simply one idea of art)

anyway, you know where this is going. mfa is not like that

reading stories and novels for years i didn’t like, maybe pre-diagnosis on a pseudo cluster-b, any author i liked was a kind of beacon, hold them tight. saunders was one of them

so this book: is it disappointing? with all i said above, obviously yes. nothing can complete with an idea. but let’s be honest: it’s fine, but definitely literary. good and bad, etc. (we forgive the sentimentality of the title story)
whyRead: - new at library, liked his older books; nervous cause the one ive read from it was some BAD missing the point on our current era

## Reflex
[[2023-10-28]]
So hard to know what to feel of this. My first Murakami. Flashes of absolute brilliance, some of the worst of his worst (until maybe the next). I find myself attempting to excuse the worst of the sexist and horny old man parts as intentional, meaningful in some coy way, but even they are, they’re done so badly, indistinguishably from what they seem like.

But the good: the [[Hangout Novel]], the still hateful self-reflection of Ushikawa, the absurd and detail free fantasy of the air chrysalis, so much more. Just wrapped in so odd a package

title: Killing Commendatore
author: Haruki Murakami
review:
[[2024-08-31]]

is it good? who knows. it's definitely near the worst of murakami, both in the quality of his work and in its genuinely cringeworthy style of sexism, so bad that it must be intentional, right, you gotta believe that to get through portions of the book. also: ain't it just a rehash of Wind-up Bird Chronicle, just worse? Like we all see that, right? The wife, the little girl, the attempt (must weaker here) to imagine the ways we connect to the violence of our social past

but complaints aside, even at his worst no one does slow-moving prose just quite like this, each segment so slow and repetitive its as though the book is questioning itself, the same way characters repeat each others words as though to question them

title: Underground
author: Haruki Murakami
review:
[[2024-07-24]]

a slight book, a shallow book, a pointless book, and all the better for it

look: let's ignore the second half with interviews of the actual Shin Aum people and just look at the first volume, which interviews victims of the subway attacks. the book is just this: description of the attack, the same events, over and over, without meaning. these things happen, these things occur, they are identical. of course, i'm lying a bit to say they're _identical_, but damn if they aren't almost the same. it's like part four of 2666, albeit a version of 2666 that just _refuses_ to add artifice (for whatever that's worth, for how possible that is). obviously they're working with entirely different events, but its interesting how the public knowledge of the subway attacks (public awareness being something we still believe, no matter what we say, works as a sort of solution) does nothing to alleviate the events. they still just the same occur. there's no surefire way to counteract

look: i believe murakami's maybe the best writer about submerged, forgotten violence that we got. this book's about violence in reality, as an uncomfortable act

title: The Corpse Exhibition
author: Hassan Blasim
content:
- First story cool and fun little monolog, second is violent yet otherwise very falltened, [[id:69535dc1-215f-47bd-ac18-c682cf53a5dc][lit fic]]
- Like story 2 is very full of vague events and details, but they seem to just be wilting in the air. This is the lit fic of it: so concerned with (a vague something I know no name for yet) that it skips over the joys and arts of fiction
- Could ofc be an intentional [[id:f858553f-85cc-40b8-8a2e-d8588570fbbe][nihilism]], given the subject, but it's a boring nihilism, not a hopeless or animated one
- Story 4 is obvs an attempt at Borges
- I do wonder if the translation is why I dislike it. Some of these stories could be endlessly hallucinogenic and fun if they werent the dullest language
- The knife stories hella fun tho
- That one paragraph in the composer!!!

one of the funniest books i’ve read in a long time, maybe since [[Helen DeWitt - The English Understand Wool (Storybook ND Series)|The English Understand Wool]], the last book of hers i read. and yet: so clearly of a different time. the office it describes exists no more

title: Some Trick
author: Helen DeWitt
review:
[[2024-09-03]]

sometimes reading a book, in my head, i note that the author must be "extremely online", a phrase which only means anything to people who spend too much time online, namely that the target of this phrase is even more online than whoever labels them it, so much so that it has warped them, the kettle calling the pot not black but rather a boiling implement, spending far too much time on the stove, to the point where _your_ metal has probably started to warp, whereas _mine_ in only stained with oil some

usually, when applied to a book, this means the author is caught up in online discourse, adding caveats that otherwise would just seem strange, or citing examples of a familiar, memetic sort (ie, only babies conceived through orgasm are ensouled. that has nothing to do with this point really, its just a tweet that will never leave my brain)

anyways, Helen DeWitt is extremely online in an incredibly different way. she is trolling stack overflow, or an obscure reddit. she has opinions on the right dialect of LaTex. one character, here, wears an xkcd shirt. and yet, despite surely knowing what's meant by meta-x, nowhere does this collection portray the expected belief in one's insurmountable implied by my stupid list of references. rather, its rather ridiculous, near humble. what does memorizing formulas and language give? in the end, the effects are neutral. no matter who you are you have to live

title: The Last Samurai
author: Helen DeWitt
content:
logbook
  1. 2024-07-23
dVIIIp29,32,37,40
review:
[[2024-08-02]]

this week, while reading the last chapters of this book, i went to see the Mountain Goats in concert. hour laters, after drinking some, i went to get pizza with friends. someone else there, by coincidence, had been to the show as well, and had stayed after to talk with John Darnielle, who'd remembered him from weeks ago, at a previous show in one of the carolinas. the kid (he was 19, i say this kindly) told us he had cried when the mountain goats played one of their songs, against pollution, caused he played it once live himself, at a guitar recital for his high school, and his favorite teacher had come to see it, a notoriously cagey man. he (the teacher), didn't stay after the show, but the kid had he email, and asked him why. days passed. there was no response. he emailed again. months passed. its been a year now. the kid who was telling this, he had had no dad, not even (referencing famous facts about the mountain goats) a shitty step dad, and his mother beat him some. so this teacher, this distant man, he wanted to be seen by him as a son. he said as much. but he couldn't email himself into feeling loved, even if he was loved. nothing is ever quite simple as that.

what i mean to say is The Last Samurai's silly, but its silly in a very emotionally heavy way. what if you could just approach a stranger you liked and ask him to be your dad? what if you read a book in order to like it?

the best book i've read this calendar year, so far

review:
[[2025-02-05]]

already from the start so clear it’ll be a great one of these social disaster novels, in that it’s never entirely clear if the authors a reactionary or just unduly brilliant at depicting reactionary characters. worse, he’s british, which to any american like me already reads a little stolid and conservative, like someone looking down their nose at the act of living. every character in this novel loves and hates the act of living, wants to feel it in themselves, destroy it in others. there can only be one who matters: only one allowed the morality of violence via their status as protagonist. why not me?

additionally: love how the violence crops up in the margin, only background static images till almost halfway through. as loose as the plot of the novel is, that really gives it a feeling of growing danger, therefore motion. the end has one of the most frightening images i’ve read
whyRead: i think i heard it was a classic of [[suburbia]] and [[paranoia]]. i’m curious as hell, and expect to love it

content:

- kill the grandmother on your shoulder lol: the book is so self conscious of hitting the right knowledge for its audience 
- so dearth of details!
review:
[[2024-08-01]]

i've got this image i work with sometimes, i call it the grandmother on your shoulder. it's a terrible corruption of the end of A Good Man is Hard to Find, where the Misfit tells the grandmother she'd be a good woman if only she'd have someone to shoot her in the head every single moment of her life. the idea is this: sometimes you get so caught up in doing things correctly, presenting the right ideas to the world, that its like you've got somebody on your back, ready to shoot you all the time. if you say anything wrong, present a lack of familiarity with whatever subject at hand, its as though she'll shoot you. so you never really get to the subject at hand. you lay down runways, caveats, signal your knowledge, and by the time you've gotten through all that, you've said nothing at all.

anyways, read between the lines whatever, ignore my preamble, this is just a real insecure book. the main character's _positioned_ as someone ignorant, naive, whatever to the book's subject, but its as though the author's scared someone might think _she_ doesn't know this, so every single page you see her hand. look: her fingers are covering your eyes. you're never gonna see a story here like that!

review:
[[2024-07-03]]

so much better than i'd of expected. maybe this should have been obvious once it was clear (in text) that this wasn't ghostwritten, but rather an adaptation of something else she wrote: a work that was _writing_ primarily, in other words, rather than artifact of a career, meant mostly to be attached to that (like how you might buy a one piece figurine because you like the series)

anyways: i feel i have little else to say on this: it's everything everyone else says that it is, a well-written and honest look at a particular person's life and mother and mental illness, honest in ways you might not expect, and achingly millennial. its a hard needle to thread, love and dependency and abuse and whatever, and though its not the best ever representation of it ever, the book does a real good job of sitting with the ambiguity, not requiring a complete explanation of catharsis. up there with Kim Gordon's autobiography, for sure

title: I Hate You-- Don't Leave Me
author: Jerold J. Kreisman
content: - genuinely oppressive his diagnosis of female celebrities!!!
review:
[[2024-11-16]]

absolutely wild this is still read, much less recommended. the start is fine, to be fair, and gives a nice and relatively concise description of the disorder (albeit with some skippable enough posthumous analyses of female celebrities, made up case studies), but then, seemingly for no reason (well, in truth for the obvious reason the author believes he’s found some key to unlock some transcendent truth, and coincidentally it means society has fallen since he was a child, when life was simple and identities were spooned until they merged), it becomes (no other word) a jeremiad. modern america is too permissive. children are self harming with tattoos. the stability of the postwar order, which we were promised was eternal, did not remain eternal, or even much stable, in truth

far from being something to skip, as in earlier chapters, this strange turn actually works to overturn the argument of the book. bpds, he tells us, are unstable. this is exacerbated if the world’s unstable too. to fix this, let’s return to an old stability, where people, at birth, are given truth. do you see the issue? this stability is false, and thus can only exist as image. is the books cure or at least treatment to fall into illusion? it claims the opposite, but this is what it demonstrates. the book devours itself, in other words

- [[2022-10-07]]: here i go again?

- this story, though, is v reminiscent of a time in my life in miami, probably because i named a charactr after lisa-lisa

- no lie though: the art is fancy detailed. not "good" perse, but fancy
- legit hard to read the comics depiction of [[Nazi]]s. it's soooo cartoony, but almost calm. like, everyones so collegiate that its reads as not so mean
  + like, a misread of indiana jones or some shut
  + its like an anti-[[Full Metal Alchemist]]: that comic admits we're the baddies. this one cant, like its outside its ability atm
  + further, even: the bull-headed obliviousness of this is like something youd see in a parody of fascist art: a commercial from [[Robocop]], etc (see, eg, ceaser's bloodline)
  + this last point even works with the no growth style: jojo simply /is/ good, no need to actually learn. (not that this is the works intent, i think)

- comparing it now to what i've seen of Stone Ocean ([[Jojo's Bizarre Adventure (anime)]]). that had a more obvious tounge and cheek feeling, more oddity mysteries to keep you going, monster people. this feels like a halfassed attemt at that (which wasn't tbh even amazing)

title: On Strike Against God
author: Joanna Russ
review:
[[2024-08-15]]

man, review is in so many ways an impossible ask. these things i write aren't even in any real way reviews, maybe reflections, but they take on that shape, maybe cause they have to. a pretext makes it easier to write

anyways, i struggle with some version of a public vs private thing, which is very pointless, as i dont really have public thoughts. i imagine rubrics for this novel based on what other people believe (so i imagine), and notice the ways it failed by this book: some unclear characters, odd pace, too much polemic, so on so on

but here's the thing: every page of its fantastic. the prose is perfect. at times, it depicts things ive not read before. so i say i love it. and i do. and then i doubt

title: Blindness
author: José Saramago
review:
[[2024-07-19]]

what a fucking book! it really is that good. i think there's so much to say about it that its not worth, in this brief reflection, to touch on most of it, so let me skip to the ending, which i think is what pushes it over the edge. because it really is, in some ways, almost a by-the-numbers societal collapse book, as might easily be codified, now, as a Walking-Dead-like (albeit significantly deeper, unpleasant, revolting strange). but then, as the main group of characters wander the ruins of their city, things take on a heavy allegorical touch, then, in an even more impactful turn, become almost like something you'd find in Dark Souls: magical fires beneath grocery markets, cathedrals whose every statue, portrait now has obscured eyes, as though someone, blind or not, has corrected god. this dark souls comparison, too, is not sudden or specious or simply surface level, just the shared fact that these images are violent and gothic: rather both use these images in a similar way, as intentionally incomplete, so that their reader is displaced from them, unsure of what exactly they have witnessed

maybe this is all a long winded way of saying i love when my postmodernism isn't metafictional. maybe im only saying i like the strange

title: (Woman) Writer
author: Joyce Carol Oates
review:
[[2024-10-05]]

it's always fun for me to read these long essay compilations by jco. they aren't specifically good or even much interesting (she's a killer writer of fiction, but very conventional wrt this stuff), but that's almost what i love about them. how else can you get such a perfect little cross section of another time. jco's ideas themselves may not be conventional (any twitter lurker knows she's a very interesting thinker, often stunningly right), but the audience she assumes, least in this collection, certainly are imagined as in hte middle of the road. so she writes to a person you can imagine, a person from a different time, before you're born. and idk, i like that, even if overall there's little of much interest otherwise

title: A Garden of Earthly Delights
author: Joyce Carol Oates
content:
- Realizing jco can parody those family sagas in her gothic novels so well because they're also exactly what she writes
- Jco must write of ugliness, so of course her white trash fantasms must be the worst of liberal imagination
- Most interesting thing in this book so far is the structure, how it rushes thru their moves and even deaths. It feels intentionally unpleasant, like an unrootedness
  - Makes it all feel a little arbitrary and meaningless: we don't get the connections between things. In fact they literally do not exist, as they're unwritten. Time pushes ever onward, unconcerned
  - Eg Clara's new job in 2.2: she just suddenly has it, without concern on struggle, only maybe as the result of the work of a man
- Overall the grotesquery makes it feel unreal
- Note that this might be her heavily revised version of the book done later into her career
- The depression was only like 30 years old when this was written. It'd be comparable to taking off Reaganomics
- White trashness is the realest focus of this, huh
- 2.4 is about the reality/unreality of Lowry in her life
  - And the the rich man Curt seems to have a power (a real one?) hidden within him
- Part 2 is all this slow sweet exuberant heightened surreal angel conversations, skipped between
- Because we don't see events but only hear about them, we don't get to know if they're real. See if Lowry's her fiance or not
- In 2.8, with Revere, she intentionally declares internally she has no interest in reality, isn't moved by it
- We have constant stories of women destroyed by their first child told by men, then we get to see Clara have a first child
- Bucking stereotypes, Clara is the main source of violence now
- 2.10: history and time are now not real
- Lowry's return really gives us a nice little dramatic novella in the middle of this
- Just as Clara has no last name, Swan has no solid name: Swan nor Steven contain him. The book is openly, playful obvious with this: the fact that his name is a symbol is more the point than the content the symbol creates at all
- With Swan's parts, the power themes are even more prevalent
- And now event event: Part 3 is all starting with novel type events
[[2022-10-25]]
- Swan refuses to see representations as the world
- and even in ch3: the starting "event" is a misscarriage
[[2022-10-26]]
- chapter four: the event is gunshots
- /until/ we get to the death... then the patterns broke
- the disorienting way events just happen, as though meaningless, arbitrary, unwanted. this is very characteristic of her work
- i feel the swan cahpters a bit of a drop, but idk why yet
- she deals with American imagery same as [[David Lynch]]: see the violence of Jonathan
- theres dangling plot thread, i think... watch out for the cousin who crushes on him yo
- the parts age backward: the dad is older than clara is older (maybe, least at their respective starts) thn Swan
- characters deal with the uncontrollability of life, even in small decisions 
- ch9s first line, plotwise, cancels out all of 8
[[2022-10-27]]
- One of the last scenes: Swan has a doctor's visit, so plain
- The rewrite was in 2002
- but it isn't so much a novel about victims as it is about the ways in which individuals define themselves and make of themselves “Americans”—which is to say, resolutely not victims.
  Her quote

author: Joyce Carol Oates

- the glass door one!
- slow start; really picks up once bianca starts talking buddhism, reincarnation
review:
longtime readers know (i am being facetious) that i’ve been attempting to read the entire published work of Joyce Carol Oates over the, oh, likely the last few years, and those most attentive know (again facetious) that every time i mention this to my mom, she brings up a book she remembers where a character from a thrown through a glass window and killed (and, as this is often over the phone, i imagine my mom in the living room in the house i went to high school in, staring out the sliding glass back door). “i just don’t get the point of all the violence,” she says (or something like it), “what’s it for?”

anyways, this is that book, finally that book, built up for me for months now. and i gotta ask the same thing. what’s this book for? jco’s so good at the meaningful, transcendent, ironic (add any adjective you like here: she’s got range, you know) about of violence.  but this one? merge that violence in with her dull, members only feeling campus satire novels….. let’s just say at this point in her career rosamund smith was the more interesting writer

title: Because It Is Bitter, and Because It Is My Heart
author: Joyce Carol Oates
review:
[[2024-08-22]]

i was scrollin the goodreads reviews for this one and got surprised how positive most of them are. to be fair, goodreads _is_ a very specific subset of _readers online_, but i was very middling on this one, and shocked to see so little middling reviews

so a theory: JCO has a lot of books, and people don't read them in chronological order over the course of years, as i'm doing now. in addition, many of her books sort of fall into "types": her absurd comedies, her prose-poet obscurities, her manic murder tales, her family-type sagas. each of these styles relies on the same sort of tricks as others of its type. thus, the more of them you read, the less surprised you are, the less novel, whatever. the novel becomes "another one of those"

this one then: my major thoughts become like "why not jsut re-read _them_. it's just so good! _them_ is so truly a fantastic, frightening book"

title: By the North Gate
author: Joyce Carol Oates
content:
- this is definitely more similiar to the first novel than the second. here we go
- This one really has got the feeling of someone pretending to know more than they do: real young person acting mature ss writing
- Census taker story good as hell tho
  - It's got those sudden moments of rushing unreal intensity like she does: realism story rules break: in this case, a child monologues
- The Faulkner influence is also WAY more obvious here, down to the focus on one small county and the use of 'we' to describe it (story 3)
- The Walpoles from Garden of Earthly Delights are mentioned
- Story 4 has that same violence of desire as in Where are you going, where have you been
- Grace's story begins the dissociation
- the focus on religion in JCO: this is where I noticed
- Wasn't tintern the new York City in Earthly Delights too?
- Lots of like prototype characters for earthly gardens really: not quite the same in details, not quite so full in character

title: Expensive People
author: Joyce Carol Oates
content:
- Showalter intro to expensive people tells us this is where the weirder baby themes jco uses start
- Claims, also, the novel is in dialog with Nabokov!
  - In, at least, that it fights back against the private, aesthetic (ascetic) novel
- Lol, jco has already beat me to the small pain intro joke! How dare she!
- This is comedy Dostoevsky
- Jco, secret lord of the pomi nonsense novel
- Fucking genius calls suburbs the slums of tomorrow in 1968
- The reveal he's 11/12: yet boldly declares a childhood that (least now) reads as younger
  - And that he acts so old, down to complaining, at 11, of blood vessel problems
- Edges, now, of parody of Proust. So ofc I love it
- Oh man, dissing flooding in 68 too. Who is this prognosticator?
- The dumb jokes are punctuated by serious plot confusions: why does he melodramatically tear the files apart?
- Is it intended irony the oil baron hates driving?
- The puns in the review chapter!
- He jumps between calling it novel, autobiography
- The review chapter, really, makes the iddest sort of move: it comments upon itself as fiction, making the narrator 100x more aware than before. So it's even weirder: a real Arnold Friend moment
- Not 100 I get this interpolated Nada story...?
- We get none of his plans or intentions, only motivations (speaking of his murder here)

title: My Heart Laid Bare
author: Joyce Carol Oates
content:
- everything i know about america i learned from joyce carol oates
- the narrator speaks in such an announcer's voice, everything feels like it
  might be a scam (this is a compliment)
- it does create a heavy-ass disatnce tho. hard to keep engaged
- there's a point though where they distance fades and the novel
  sings. i remember why JCO's distanced style works. you get two views
  of the characters simultaneously, a public and a private, of which
  two thoughts
  1) v. fitting the content of this book: con artists who themselves
     have to balance the half-form truth and the complete image
  2) all the gothic novels are about public life --- down to the most
     recent being mostly real life historical figures --- so this
     style perfectly matches the subject. you have to engage with the
     distant and powerful, as you might with (contemporarily to the
     book) bill clinton or OJ simpson, or bill gates
- as well, the end (2 parts away) feels like SUCH a build up. nice

title: Mysteries of Winterthurn
author: Joyce Carol Oates
content:
- she jumps into the old style with this one, down to fake intros
- once it gets into the supernatural 'mystery', it REALLY picks up
- taking a break after part 2: no supernatural, just oddly incomplete
  feeling detective stories
- the philosophy book bit is killer. Moving the quotes to make the jokes
- Its like a niche [[Garth Marenghi - Garth Marenghi’s TerrorTome|Garth Marenghi’s TerrorTome]], ain’t it
- We’re much more in the realm of [[Joyce Carol Oates - Bellefleur|Bellefleur]] than [[Joyce Carol Oates - A Bloodsmoor Romance|A Bloodsmoor Romance]] here. But with additional grisly murder, almost as a joke
- The parodies of newspapers in book 2 are such calls on like true crime now, geez
- Explicitly a male narrator!!
- It’s hard I guess to tell explicitly what’s meant to be funny about X. Like, is he a bad detective? Too obsessive? Too right? The vagueness of him makes it a little hard to grasp, though I feel there is something there. Are we detecting? A social novel? Too many things at once?
- (At the start of quicksand chapter) I think I remember this chapter
- Find you someone who hates America as much as Joyce Carol Oates! Goddamn
- The little hints of the supernatural in this case are so nice, as though even reality’s pov differs from the American peoples
- per the afterward, her fave of the quintet
	- also: inspired by lovecraft fiction (the supernatural, now, ofc)

title: Soul/Mate
author: Joyce Carol Oates
review:
[[2024-07-15]]

Maybe the definitive example of a mid JCO thriller. It has a lot of the elements of her better ones (killers, breathless prose, boundlessly uncomfortable (to bourgeois eyes) desires), but none of them much get to something. It just sort of... occurs. It is, to misuse Vonnegut, what it pretends to be.

Maybe this is what the Rosamond Smith4 novels are, though: a place to finish uninteresting novels.

review:
[[2024-12-07]]

This one's for the real JCO sickos, which is to say I loved it. Her last like 5-10 I read were all misses, so maybe I was primed for a good one, but I ate this in a day. Violent, unpleasant, straightforward. A perfect non-comedy Oates. I love when she writes a character like this (she's done it many times before): a woman who fully believes she has no agency or will enacting this nihility unknowingly. Just perfect. The pain I crave from a novella.

title: them
author: Joyce Carol Oates
content:
- Here we get our realest first glimpse of our classic jco pampered, seen, desired high school girl (in 1937)
- Jco differs in the 'silent suffering' literary style because the characters don't simply focus on their complaints; they have violent desires, needs, etc. And worse issues more often than not, but that's a little beside the point
- Notable that so far she reserves her serious tone for the poor, her satiric for the middle classes
- How these first chapters are just a rewrite of [[id:4ca581e5-f575-483e-bf0e-629b25d3a15f][garden of earthly delights]]
- Characters more or less vanish into new characteristics between chapters, burnt out
- There's a harsh feeling in this---the casual way things just happen---that nothing at all matters. Life is meaningless and it just goes on and on
  - It's a dead eyed, dispassionate [[id:06479437-2bc7-4a25-a44b-a5ee0f0c488e][Kleist]], ain't it?
- Characters constantly yearn, uncertain even themselves what for
- Note the real/fake theme in this sucker
- Is Maureen our first real dissociating woman? Before, I think they were all yearning and cruel, full collaborators maybe
- The reserve in where are you going it's so much clearer with this, where she does go there
- Part 1 ends on the final violent act, the one that feels significant
- Faye is SUCH a different, radiant character: this books version of Charlus
- Jules and Faye is so clearly a version of Maureen and her man that it HAS to be interesting
  - And the sweeping melodramatic convos in part of the earthly delights
- Reminds me also a lot of that ragtime book I read so long ago. Was that DH Lawrence? Or EL Doctorow
- Like gardens, shifts styles between parts. We've gone from [[id:0c79e439-0863-4ad8-b55c-ee0396f87d6a][Faulkner]]escent I to [[id:6b097da7-b1a5-4875-b3eb-3425fba68b45][Proust]]/Sister Carrie II
- Holy God at the end of Bernard!
- Faye is gone too?????
- These absolute plot destroying moments really help differentiate JCO from who she's imitating: there is no solidity, even in social order, here
- I love the anti romance of the long road trip
- This is all very American [[id:E8100409-9506-4A2B-A27E-455540136DDB][David Lynch]] shit
- Opposite of Homestuck: all but the most intense moments are skipped over
- Jules being my great grandpa out thru the gulf south now, huh
- Maureen's letters are so like my own specific fear of the world, my god. It's uncomfortable reading
- the impossible and strange ways things keep coming back
- its like a brechtian melodrama, ne: so put upon, soap operatic, fake
- Competing versions of real make up the climax
- This last scene in part II is drawn out because the end of it MUST cause a change, and we anticipate it
- Gonna be honest tho, didn't expect her to shoot him
- The racism is real ass unpleasant
- Such a theme of hopelessness, huh
- Odd how Loretta moves out of sympathy by the end of this, as of narrator's given up on her
- The Detroit riots section is so interesting now, for being so contemporary to a thing now (lamely) revered
- This is a real Novel-ass novel
- The attempts.to show racism at this point just feel racist (pt3)
review:
Much more explosive, ridiculous, fragmented, unwell than her previous books (major compliment: my fav so far). At times, it pretends to be an early 20th century naturalist social novel (akin to me doing, what, a fake sixties road novel?), but its never /quite/ coherent enough. It's shifts into soap operatic melodrama, mystic violence, and other solidity-denying things too often, denying the very social reality it describes. Again, a major compliment. This IS the way of life in the American empire: one of fantasy.
Somewhere Oates said she wrote this quartet to describe how much she hated America, and god damn if this one doesn't show it. Fantastically grim.
(Also worth a note: the racism of the characters is /obviously/ meant to be a display of Midwest racism, but she did /not/ succeed. imo, it leans a little too much into it, so as to actually seem racist.)

review:
[[2024-07-11]]

hard to not just praise this. i'm not sure when or how i learned that judith butler writes more than just about the gender theory they're famous for, but god if that isn't some of their best work, which i've applied to my own life at least more than once.

this book, then, it cool development in that: they talk about that same political material, and connect it back to their gender theory: why are people so afraid of gender? if we use the assumptions we've built from Gender Trouble, which contradict these gender fears, then how do we explain and understand these fears? what is actually feared or lost?

i don't think i can summarize this well (writing this tired), but one of the best books i've ready this year so far

title: Black Paradox
author: Junji Ito
review:
[[2024-08-12]]

what a nice one! i think its the first junji ito full-length i read that _doesn't_ involve some sort of world-ending calamity, some massive impossible disaster, but instead smaller and slower moving things, and atop that more character driven. i think ito's a real like... if you let me use my prose-writer's terms he's a real short stories guy, who even in his longer works just drops short story after short story into the main text, endlessly extractable little bits. never, though, does that work better than it does here, where allowing the characters to, more than ever, take the lead in the shape of the thing, each little diversion into self-contained sections really feels natural, inevitable, correct. the parts are truly there within the whole

also: god how many weird meme images online actually come from junji ito. i had no clue. i've seen our wonderful robot stomach friend from this one online _several_ times

title: Dissolving Classroom
author: Junji Ito
review:
[[2024-08-19]]

Junji Ito comedy is good! Junji Ito comedy is nice! There's not a lot of depth to it, if we're being fully honest, but that aint the point of it really, is it?

Of more interest, then: it is _hella_ notable h0w Junji Ito just like... can't write an active character to save his life, least not an active protagonist. Here, of what I've read so far, he comes the closest: the main character of the first chapter is actually active, as hell, so of course she ends up injured and out of the story! Is there a way we try to understand this? I can't tell.

title: Gyo
author: Junji Ito
review:
[[2024-08-05]]

prolly the first “good” ito original full length i’ve read, in the sense that it feels like a unified thing, not a collection of stories that sprout a mythos all at once. and it’s so well done! i think i’ve had this impression of ito from mostly before reading his one shots that he struggled to carry ideas, was just good at images, but damn am i wrong about that! and glad of it. i think the real highlight is the sudden circus, the joy and chaos. there’s a strength in both comedy and horror in leaving things unresolved, and that circus hits the mark

title: Museum of Terror - The Long Hair in the Attic
author: Junji Ito
review:
[[2024-09-17]]

this has been a real fun one to read after a stint of ito's later book length works. not only is the drawing style charmingly simpler, as though (one imagines) the smudges remain on the page, but also the characters are more stock, the endings faster, the situations sillier. i realize this sounds negative, reading it over now, but i feel quite the opposite: this is some of the collection's strength. i remember some maybe apocryphal tale about early chekhov stories, someone read them and said, hey chekhov, your talent's too good for silly tales like this, i can see the genius in them already. feels the same with early ito, so i say this to both of them: what you're seeing is not only glimmer of genius. it is genius itself. genius can be a part of silly things

title: No Longer Human
author: Junji Ito
review:
[[2024-08-16]]

i will never be able to read this book untainted. No Longer Human, the original work, is one of my favorite novels, and let me tell you, it’s not the plot that makes it one of my favs. it’s all in the tone of the book, its aching ambivalence, the lack of emotion, the refusal to entertain even the most obvious excuses for why Oba is, as he’d call it, bad. easiest example, ofc, is the sexual assault early on in the book, which clearly destroys a little of his head. where in Ito we get it depicted outright, tits up and all, recurring and resonant, Dazai doesn’t even mention it outright. nothing made me this way, Yozo maintains: i have simply always been wrong 

ito, conversely, makes it a melodrama. he drops in horror images that kick straight ass. but i still can’t get through to enjoy it. it’s not what i’m used to at all. i’m like a child refusing frosted flakes. i ate raisin bran before

title: Remina
author: Junji Ito
review:
[[2024-08-06]]


this is it. this is where ito hits his stride. is this not killer? the completeness of this world, the thematics. there’s a strong argument to make that itos protagonists are always passive, simply watching things unfold, but only here does that serve any thematic importance (ofc one could argue, still, this is too far). one reminas the ideal passive woman, one destroys. and what a fucking terrifying planet remina is!

title: Uzumaki
author: Junji Ito
review:
[[2024-07-25]]

Like the subject of a horror story, perhaps, or a long-prophesied event, i heard of this book hundreds of times before i read it, glanced at it on shelves at barnes and nobles, snickered, flipped through on slow dull days when i later worked at a bookstore... It cannot be reviewed. To pretend I have any aesthetic opinions on it would be a lie, as I can only compare it to an imagined version of it built up over many years, impossibly meaningful in the way only abstract things can be, like death, escape, transcendence. It is symbol first, and manga after....

Yeah, anyways, its pretty good. The balance between the monster-of-the-week stuff and the larger story's a bit off, but otherwise it's killer.

title: Berserk
author: Kentaro Miura
content:
if someone questions its porniness, tell them be honest: it _is_ that kind of story, just a good one

## Notes
### Black Swordsman
-   how do i not have notes yet lol. i musta deleted by mistake. its good
### Golden Era
-   2022-09-30: so gothic literary: born of death, brings over death. he's literally like 'from nothing', a synonym for irredeemable
-   2022-10-01: the slow way this next chapter starts after he kills gambino: it shows it as a self-destroying tragedy. this pity party only makes sense after the last arcs 'cool guy business': its a contrast yo
-   they constantly draw young guts with cutie eyes: he is an innocent child despite this, etc. maybe the pain made him more, internally, inocent
-   griffith feels way more complicated in this. was he like that on tv too? or is it b we know, in this, he becomes a demon?
-   2022-10-08: guts is also like a little kid in the manga. it adds to the character a lot, ya know
    -   i was wrong on this. he's young in the anime too
-   it speeds through 'real' battles to luxuriate in the demon fight with Zodd
-   "that there's some huge something beyond human understanding in this word… gods… devils… same thing"
-   2022-10-09: because griffith is such a mystery, Casca's feeling about him are one too. we're not *quite* in guts' head (too elusive), but we do only get the present info he can know (about his leaders: the ones who want him dead we know)
    -   another way to say this: she becomes a major character cause we want to understand her desire
    -   or, to rephrase in the comics words, "a dream": this—desire—is the only thing to cross class lines
    -   these "dreams" too, as said by griffith, are connected to a meaning for living
    -   further: they are *equal* to will, where *desire* is not
-   also: griffith's girlyboyness—plus the cruelty of the people he takes out—mke him feel like the good guy by default. kinda uses our genre expectations to build that
-   our villian breaks off after naming what Guts is to Griffith, alerting us that this shits gonna matter a lot: dying words
-   really though: the level of child sex abuse is so much its basically thematic: 2/3 of our main character so far, and now a backstory of a noble involved in it
    -   make that 3/3, but griffith as a willing sacrifice, as recompense (not quite the word) for his dream
-   "maybe my dream is what killed htis boy"
    -   "my dream can only be realized by building on their corpses"
-   again: Casca hints at Guts being a 'something' of griffiths
-   the fights: so intricately detailed, still so boring to me
-   and here: Guts shows a very unexpected sweet side: he *knows* everyone in his troop, which is outside expected character
-   2022-10-10: today sara said: "i get why boys like it. its a story about masculinity"
-   the griffith womanlyness is no mistake
-   often, we get slices of melodrama to build subplots: i am speaking of the queen whose mistress (affair partner?) griffith has assassinated
-   2022-10-14: now, later on, the courtly stuff aint boring because all the context is there: i can deal with a thing i dont like in fantasy lol
-   2022-10-15: The slow rise of demons after Griffith drops his necklace is….. Fascinating really. We know they're there, but this feels like a different reality from then…. They're passing between
-   And the meaning of each 'type' of demon: is the skelly good? Is puck bad?
-   2022-10-16: we get potential meanings for symbols too: is the skelly night the old emporer we see in flashback?
-   its all *significantly* more emotional than advertised (this is a positive). griffith's re-discovery in the dungeons, eg, is played not for gore but sentiment
    -   which then makes the descriptions of torture after worse: we read these as happening to someone about whom we care, not just a comic caricature
-   immediately followed by hyperviolence, which leaves me cold, indifferent
-   unlike griffith eye closeups, which tell us nothing about his thoughts, only that he *is* thinking
-   the violence now is getting *real* extreme (the rape monkey scene)
    1.  is it simply bad taste? is it intentional?
    2.  it really builds a whole `criminal == bad` argument too, as if this were Law and Order SVU
-   the face art in demon world…..cool as hell
-   so hard to tell if silent griffith wants this… he only *wills*
-   Guts made griff forget his dream: turned him, in other words, human
-   its harsh, watching guts talk to the dying version of all his named comrades
-   "this is to be human… this is to be evil," a demon says as griffith ascends
-   "this is the reality you must walk through from here on," the skull knight tells guts
-   guts fights against the term "destiny"
-   terms: dreams, destiny, will, want
-   guts dream: violence unto demons. how do we analyze or feel onthis?
-   Casca's child (lets here just skim over the way her womanness is done now… unsure how to read it (yet)) is another Guts, to the extreme: born of horrible death
-   Guts is given option to stay with ppl, including casca, instead of revenge, doesnt

title: With Teeth
author: Kristen Arnett
content:
- assimilationist af lol---to ve a member of the self concoisly sad borgies
- note for later, on my opinion: i get that the characters meant to be a little delusional/self-involved, but because the book is so [[id:69535dc1-215f-47bd-ac18-c682cf53a5dc]['lit fic']] in its scope/methods/whatever, there's seemingly no belief in a world outside her. this is what i feel with the other character pov sections especially: these characters dont matter to the world beyond how they exist under the [[id:b889ca21-1690-480b-ab4c-1e035c8692a9][Shadow of the "I"]] of Sammie. so it fails to do this mean first person character. 
- further on that: b/c it has the lit fic assumption of shared bougie meanings, the book /cant/ have any deeper POV. its so reliant on these lists of meaninglessly meaningful details that its like... self-conscious you might think that its self-conscious(??? at the wording of this)
- Our main character is a "special girl": her super power is being--- notably to other characters--- just so broken and sad
- All the shirt other characters povs show the shallowness for real lol
- Story only really starts halfway thru, which seems.... Characteristic of something

content:

review:
[[2024-11-20]]

## 1, a joke: 
my message to lacanians: i doubt the written word as much as you, but can’t we agree, just for the moment, to play within the rules of its lies?

## 2, a serious reflection :
i loved the central idea of this book. its simple in a way that makes you feel you already know it, its just self evident, it was already there just out of sight, you were already effected

## 3, a confession:
this book is as much about that idea as it about alfred hitchcock. it is primarily aesthetic analysis. this disappointed me, as it was not what i expected. i became therefore dismissive in my reading, as this was not my desired book, so i might almost say i never read it. i skimmed a cliff notes. it would be unfair to say otherwise

title: War and Peace
author: Leo Tolstoy
content:
- keeping with my "I love long novels" trend: the longest novel people think of from the top of their heads. so wild to me how tolstoy, noted anarchist, writes such mannered, european prose, especially given russian lits more... edgy(?) feel. it reminds me of the french stuff. i guess that's st petersburg, the same way an american novel will feel different in the "provinces" vs the northeast/other old colonial midwests. that said, i'm one "book" in. this could all be setup (though i remember anna karenina feeling the same)
- 3 books in: feel the same
- 4 books: i do get the Grossman Life and Fate vibes for sure, but it just hasn't drawn me in. i guess it fits why its a 'history' not a 'novel' (per tolstoys opinions)
- i liked the one book, the one with the gambling plot. this most recent one---the masons and the peasants plot---was also ok, but didnt hit as well as the last. its not quite a "hangout" book, like you might hope from something so long, but im for sure not hating it
- such a long fox hunting scene, my gott!
- overall, just a real up and down :/. The melodrama, i love. The social hierarchy stuff, well ok. but sometimes its just intolerably european and old
- book 9, so far, i have liked. the mix of philosophy in it is great, and beyond the first monolog on war, real well integrated into the characters. its the classic "things heat up at the halfway", spread over something so large
- book 9 is great. i have to say it. its where it hits its stride
- book 10 has not matched 9 yet.... back to the slow parts. we'll see if that builds once it becomes a real war
- [[2021-09-09]]: lol was that wrong. the wars are if anything more boring: historical reports rather than dramatic events
- [[2021-09-22]]: maybe i just dont like this, lol

title: Bliss Montage
author: Ling Ma
content:
# rev
[[2024-11-26]]

life is pretty alienating now, huh? you ever noticed this, that the lives we live sometimes feel like someone else is living it, and we're just watching from afar [x8]

i want to claim this all on its own irritated me out of liking this collection, the shallow repetition of the same theme without much interest in going deeper, but lets be honest, i read murakami, i'm very forgiving of that. in truth, i just disliked the prose style, all clipped and stark, workaday as well-made software documentation. it simply wasn't fun to read, and that's enough to transform me into a heterodox, intellectual hater. i wanted something more. if i'm going to be alienated, as we all are, might i not at least have pleasure also?

title: My Death
author: Lisa Tuttle
review:
[[2025-03-13]]

a nice one, though still more on the style of [[Lisa Tuttle - The Curious Affair of the Somnambulist and the Psychic Thief|The Curious Affair of the Somnambulist and the Psychic Thief]] than [[Lisa Tuttle - A Nest of Nightmares|A Nest of Nightmares]], which is a shame but i guess almost a necessity of the novel as a form: its slower, often not read at once, therefore less like a sudden wound. but i did really enjoy the way it sort of had it both ways, had two endings. it wasnt ambiguous, rather it contradicts itself. as with the Somnambulist novel, it makes me want to read more from her
whyRead: - really liked her short stories in [[Lisa Tuttle - A Nest of Nightmares|A Nest of Nightmares]] and wanted to try a novel that wasnt a straightforward detective novel like [[Lisa Tuttle - The Curious Affair of the Somnambulist and the Psychic Thief|The Curious Affair of the Somnambulist and the Psychic Thief]]

title: The Curious Affair of the Somnambulist and the Psychic Thief
author: Lisa Tuttle
review:
[[2025-01-27]]

truth be i can’t say that i didn’t enjoy it, but it was as though i were on edge the whole time: was it an act of ironic performance? a serious interest in the genre? in the end, i believe it was sincere, and unfortunately to its own detriment. this is only my taste, of course: a supernatural mystery, if base on the supernatural, isn’t much interesting to me. i want controlling metaphors! i want unclear worlds beyond belief! that said, i liked it a lot. i’m a sicko for a mystery

title: The Lais of Marie de France
author: Marie de France
review:
[[2024-06-24]]

reading real old books is always strange. this one’s from the whole ass eleventh or twelfth century, and it feels like an entirely different world. the lack of details, the heavy reliance on complimenting the main characters as the best in the land. it’s like a constant reminder (don’t know if it’s true or not) that these stories were written for a small aristocratic class. we’re at least moderately more open in our literature now

also fascinating: how many tropes are that old. there’s legit a tense confrontation over a chess board. in the eleventh or twelfth century! with almost no tension or atmosphere involved!

title: In The Beginning was the Command Line
author: Neal Stephenson
content:
I use a Macintosh computer for work. I use Linux as my main OS at home. For the majority of my text editing---including the prose of this review---I use emacs, which is so customizable God probably had less options those first few days he spent putting together the garden of eden. I use it to track my reading. I like to us my basic knowledge of computer systems to enhance my activities too.

I am not being clear, I think. I am insulting Mr. Stephenson. I do not think these facts about myself---nor my ability, just like Mr. Stephenson, to hyper-obsess on useless information I don't effect in my daily life (undersea cables for him, the habits and output of the most singular, ineffable internet microcelebrities for me)---are very interesting or worth writing about.

Here /is/ something interesting about myself: late one night in Ybor city, which is in Tampa, I thought I might take a shortcut through an alley to avoid an outdoor hookah bar I didn't like. I figured I'd also get to save some time. Instead, though, the alley bent and turned around more buildings, and within a few minutes, tracing what was in essence a straight line, I was more lost than I'd ever been before. Maybe there's a metaphor in there somewhere. Maybe if I had the same self-surety Mr. Stephenson has here, I might even think I knew.

- how the changing in speech lasts till the end. how it frightens the judge
review:
[[2024-08-09]]

Incredible book, much more than i expected from the premise, heck more than i expected even from the author, who i really like. i think its easy to believe, sight unseen or whatever, that any sort of "rewriting" of a famous story will be one sided, or at least flat, in that it might require an understanding of the original, or conversely that it'll try to be so different as to be all but separate, like Shakespeare plays to Amanda Bynes's "[[She's The Man]]". but this one works so well slotted into Huck Finn or not. it hits that border

perfect example: an early subversion of the original is that James doesn't _actually_ talk like n-word Jim in Huck Finn, its just an act slaves do as some protection. great joke and everything, as well as a wonderful way to get out of having to actually write a character like the original Jim, but later, once the book has set itself another path, that earlier joke comes back in an incredibly effective, original way. its both a joke on Huck Finn and an important thematic element outside it

honest: this is a hard one for me to review atm, the day after finishin it. is it good? or rather, more unclear to me, did i enjoy it? theres that stupid meme of of people reading books in public and shaking their head performatively to show they don't endorse it, and that's sort of how i feel on this one, except replace "reading in public" with "enjoying the book". like, on just a prose and structure level i loved it. one of the better novels in fragment i've ever read (and i fucking love the style). but god, was i happy to be done. i was so happy to be away from this mean-girl narrator, this person who has it all and doesn't care (or whatever facile language you'll accept here). maybe a few years later i'll know. maybe i'll get it

i guess my feeling now is this: how much of this feeling i have is author intentional? how much is just me not liking the book?

let’s go ahead and get this out of the way: terrible prose style. worst i’ve read in a while, if only for trying so hard to make _some_ kind of voice, though one that seems as honest as a badly conceived lie. at the end dude admits to being a radio dj, which perhaps explains it. i imagine all radio djs sound like that

anyways, the content itself is pretty interesting. there’s a very interesting contradiction in old brenda’s life, though i feel the books only like strutting the edges of it, giving us like plausibly deniable suppositions, never deeper thoughts. i wanted less single paragraph dummy punches of how serious everything was about to be and more in depth of why it was serious and what that might mean

review:
[[2024-11-07]]

i tore through this one, and not just cause i was reading it during the election. it’s just so propulsive and fun! postmodern meta fiction-light, but as a little joke much more than anything. i wanna drop in how it was slighter than i expected, and dropped in that slingshot ending a _little_ to earlier to be effective, but my god, who cares, give me some oddly phrased descriptions, tell me about the ancient history of the novel, throw in so much yapping enthusiasm for everything from tarot to future political geography that i, the reader, am almost _forced_ to drop into autobiographical criticism and say Only a 26 year old could have written this, even though everyone knows that thought is facile, do it again

my favorite delaney so far

title: Folklore, Horror Stories, and the Slender Man
author: E. Newsom, Shira Chess
review:
[[2024-08-11]]

the slender man is the ultimate father figure. the slenderman is the terrible image of the bourgeois man

i think i seeked this one out after watching Jane Schoeburns early youtube doc about slender man, [[A Self-Induced Hallucination]] (wonderful title, btw) and yelling at the tv like a sportsfan about how there is no societal meaning to be found from the slenderman stabbings. sometimes horrible events just occur. and where that doc sort of looked at failures tointerpret slenderman via, i guess, traditional moral panic views, this book fills in the other side, the view of slenderman as a folklore figure, USED for meaning rather than meaningful itself

idk, i really liked it

- [[2022-10-15]]: the sort of stuff about believing through non-belief.... very cool
- The point that removing all individual ethnic character in favor of abstract citizenship favors the major group: very white American
- Concept: Homo sacer
- Zizek's point that the Real feels most Unreal when it is most noticeable

title: Duma Key
author: Stephen King
review:
[[2025-04-30]]

102.5 the bone. 102.5 the bone. The book takes place in the Tampa area the same time _i_ lived in the Tampa Bay Area, so how could I not be served by this. Further, it feels like king was trying to write a murakami (much as he could), what with the pace, the doubled characters, even (in a way unseen since Pet Semetary, his uncontested best) skirting up to the line of depicting middle American men as subconsciously violent, that most murakami of themes. The ends thus a bit of a shame, falling into a more explicit thus duller thriller, but hey, the rest is great. I loved it

review:
[[2024-07-09]]

the “literary” king story collection, in the most disparaging way. sometimes (when i’m being quite the hater) i think of lit fics defining quality as a shallow empathy, a refusal or inability to imagine the lives of others without first making their desires match or at least align with yours, a sort of sorting of the allowable social. is this true? i don’t know, sometimes? at the very least, it’s true about stephen kings essays into literary fiction: feelings must be contained and explained. that makes the, literary. that makes them no longer frightening, thrilling. the stories become dull and static, as a result

title: Regarding the Pain of Others
author: Susan Sontag
content:
# Quotes
- “To speak of reality becoming a spectacle is a breathtaking provincialism. It universalizes the viewing habits of a small, educated population living in the rich part of the world, where news has been converted into entertainment—”
- “one of the characteristics of modernity is that people like to feel they can anticipate their own experience.”
- “It is a view of suffering, of the pain of others, that is rooted in religious thinking, which links pain to sacrifice, sacrifice to exaltation—a view that could not be more alien to a modern sensibility, which regards suffering as something that is a mistake or an accident or a crime. Something to be fixed. Something to be refused. Something that makes one feel powerless.”
- “the daily bombing operations in Afghanistan in late 2001 and early 2002 were directed from U.S. Central Command in Tampa, Florida.”
- “as Simone Weil affirms in her sublime essay on war, “The Iliad, or The Poem of Force” (1940), violence turns anybody subjected to it into a thing.”
review:
[[2024-10-28]]

two points, paraphrased from quotes i copied from this book:
1. one characteristic of modernity is wanting to master an experience before its had
2. "reality as spectacle" (wrt violence) is a narrow, entertainment focused point of view
thusly:
3. each act of violence is converted into a measurable, discrete _thing_, rather than an event. though still suffering, this is easier to handle than the impossible, meaningless _event_. a photograph is a version of this _thing_

sorry: i liked this enough to take notes instead of review it. hahaha

It was good! I'm writing this more than a week out from finishing it, so I've forgot a lot, but I recall the strange shape of it, which created sadness.

title: Between the World and Me
author: Ta-Nehesi Coates
review:
[[2025-04-17]]

two things i dont like in contemporary lit fic:
1. lists of details with little development within them. i think of it as like a holdover from the whole literature of exhaustion stuff from like 70s, 80s, but without the intent to exhaust, only the sort of 'literary flair' left there
2. sentences that sort of stay in one place, as tho they're describing one moment forever frozen in time. as with point one above, its fine if used intentionally, but so often it seems a shortcut too literary cleverness, as let's be honest, writing a sentence like that can be pretty tough on a craft-based basis. but ice sculptures as well as pretty cool

i list these out not to diss this book but to praise it, cause yeah, you know, Ta-Nehesi Coates is a big offender of both these tics i claim to hate. yet i love everything ive read by him (so far). i think its mostly the content of his work, you know: the meanings behind the not-to-my-taste prose. there's a strong, earnest attempt to describe difficult things in each of his books, and a truly impressive honesty about himself in each. i mean, i wish i had the insight to describe this better, i wish i could go further than the obvious stuff about him that's sort of just in the air or known. because he describes these difficult things both simply, in that there's never a point you can't quickly understand, and complexly, in that nothing about their infinitely detailed surfaces is smoothed over. its like, what if somebody pointed out and described a sphere in a way that let you know, in little words, about each divot and bump, so you could roll it across the earth with the proper amazement that so flawed a thing still rolled? thats what its like

title: Corrections
author: Thomas Bernhard
content:
- I envision the Cone as the polyhedron from Pathologic
- Does the single sentence style make you wanna read things more symbolic? Is that even a theme, or does my long sentence make me imagine that?
- Our Austran boys are very negative, and in such bougie, propert based ways
- big theme of giving self up
- Are we meant to view the Cone ironically, as a silly goal? I can't tell. Maybe it's both: we see the joke and are told of it's greatness, so as to have to hold both ideas in our head
- The endless sentences actually make it easier to dip in and out: it's a sort of continuous endless thing, no matter where you stop, lest you plan ahead to read the whole thing
- Is altensaam a made up place, the character's home, maybe
- The long sentences also let it shift sneakily into Rot's first person: syntax , man
- In other words, more self erasing/shifting
- Sneaky sentence ender: rot kills himself, an aside: in regards to how they like each other's houses
- Correction is an interesting title, now with prose and suicide in it. Implied now, his death is a "correction"
- Rot believes something is destroyed by corrections made to it
  - It is "corrected out of existence"
- H becomes R becomes I
- The identity shift is v much shown in the apartments and how identically they're treated there
- Presents before the end of first half that the cone is what kills his sister
- The story with the circular syntax really repeats stuff, as if coming in and out of subjects of note
- Walk to school becomes suddenly not only a metaphor for life, but also a way to make the river gorge the house is on a symbol, changing it's meaning a little from before
- The long sentences, esp near the end of chapter 1, really feel like putting things off, as tho maybe nervous
- Yo, he really hates Austria
- Did we know he was sick before?
- Narrators shift seeming to be Away from Rot's pov
- Hoellers house really is like a haunted house deal
- The further this goes, on not editing etc, the more I feel I accidentally parodied it years ago
- was i meant to be spoiled on why his sis dies? i cant tell
- this parts (2) gets crazy negative! the despair ne? the suicide
- aligns suicide with the creation of art in here: a cousin speaks of it as tho "completed"... completely understood (235)
- y now, sudden misogyny
- does he ever talk of the narrator? i think not
- the shorter dated parts feel like a speeding up, a rising manicness, unpleasant
- the Rot of II is not like I: he is led by drives, not intellect

title: V
author: Thomas Pynchon
review:
[[2026-01-09]]

is it good? sporadically. pynchon's always been secretly a short story writer, with elaborate silly plots to connect each little narrative he has, so maybe lets put it like this: the short stories in this one are already brilliant, more straightforward (perhaps) than they'll become but otherwise the same as you might find later in, say, against the day. its the connective overall plot that's not there yet, more clearly an excuse for action, so on so on. maybe also its because the plot recurs in [[Thomas Pynchon - The Crying of Lot 49|Lot 49]] and [[Thomas Pynchon - Gravity's Rainbow|Gravity's Rainbow]], each handling a different part, and improving it lots. want a detective yarn about pointless searching: lot 49's got you. want a cross continental zany nightmare: there's a reason its the V2 rocket, its the sequel meant to overtake the first

title: Vineland
author: Thomas Pynchon
review:
[[2025-11-12]]

it’s really hard to know what i think of this. at times it reads like an amazing connection of interconnecting stories. at times it’s disappointingly discursive. in a way it comes together in the end, in a way it doesn’t 

the peak moment though: the end when it returns to prarie. all this shit, this mess, all these fathers. by coincidence it led to her. this is clearly nice. its the heart, so it seems, of my reading, and makes me want to look at it again
whyRead: - a podcast covered it, i wanted to reread anyway

title: Lolita
author: Vladimir Nabokov
content:
![cover|150](http://books.google.com/books/content?id=utvB0I_0SZsC&printsec=frontcover&img=1&zoom=1&edge=curl&source=gbs_api)

logbook: 
 - [[2023-03-22]] - [[2023-03-27]]: audiobook
## Notes

## Reflex
[[2023-03-28]]
Honestly: both better and different than I remembered. The prose style is so over the top, honestly, that it /has/ to go metaphysical. If it's calling such attention to itself, it becomes central. It's a text about a text, hidden behind its content.

And its content: it's /much/ worse than advertised. It's /solely/ reliant on its reader to hate it, the moral version of an incredibly dry joke. So of course I love that. It's got hella issues---hella issues---but I tend to be ok with them, for the attempt.

All though, of course, it's meant to be salacious. That's meant to gather readers etc. That's part the point of it.

(Final thought: odd to read this now, so forward, so modern, when it's from before my parents were born. Lolita is older than them, I mean the character. No conclusion to that thought yet.)

## Themes

- [[Freud]]

title: Stories
author: Vladimir Nabokov
content:
- enjoyable enough (if light so far)
- the intro get VERY weird real quick once you realized it was
  written by his literal son, though. classify it as another one of
  those distances between the aristocracy and the rest of us
- the first stories, imo, were kinda dull---just his
  pyrotechnics---but as it goes on, thy do get a lot better. still
  havent quite made my cup of tea yet, but i'm only a quarter of the
  way through. ww2 hasnt even happened yet, historically speaking
- real up and down, as often goes. like i said above, older
  stories. different time. now and then you get a glimpse of the later
  nabokov, and that is always pleasant as all hell. he's yet to write
  a charming charlatan character though, so there's the feeling
  this'll get better, just around the bend
- these get /real/ good, but theyre hard to read all in a row. they're
  too complex, varied, and occasionally dull. perhaps why i am
  SLOGGING through the book, though not ready to ever give up
