title: A Canticle for Leibowitz
author: Walter M. Miller
content:
![cover|150](http://books.google.com/books/content?id=idFaAAAAYAAJ&printsec=frontcover&img=1&zoom=1&source=gbs_api)

dIXp131,141,147

- this is like _immediately_ good, lol. im shook
- florida catholic as well
review:
[[2025-05-27]]

Damn. God damn. Holy shit. Been a few days since this one, but I still feel the ending. It’s not the only story I’ve read that ends with nuclear Armageddon like this (1. Just read a king short story that does 2. A big somewhat irrational fear of mine), but really it’s the grim pessimism before the bombs that make it hit. It’s like a structure of a terrible horrible little magic trick: watch this species; it had no meaning; it fights and dies; and look, now it is gone. 

Maybe it’s even stronger for the first part, which is mostly silly. We get to see humans as lesser than us and then, with time, better than us but still just as deluded, confused, destructive, maybe hopeless. Maybe it’s the conviction. I don’t know. 

In summary: books as grim as it is good.

title: Nueromancer
author: William Gibson
review:
[[2025-02-13]]

i did _not_ like it. i think its the classic hater reason: you hear something talked up so much you're gonna hold it to a higher standard, but still, it didn't hit for me. this is my third time trying to read it in so many years, and the only time i've finished, so its definitely not for lack of trying! i _wanted_ to like this a lot. i wanted to like this the way a character in a bad 1990s comedy wants to be let into a club by a rude bouncer, imagining there's something great inside, some new belonging. but it was all light and sound, shined clean aesthetics. i wanted something more than perfect prose. i'm just not so drawn by the competent loser trope (?)

title: The Lucky Star
author: William T. Vollmann
review:
[[2024-09-30]]

Is it wrong to call so long, so intense, so complete a novel half baked? no not all, obviously, if i thought that why would i say it, but still, it feels weird or at least backward enough that i wish to explain it. yesterday i made some shortbread cookies and didn’t add enough butter, so they ended up crumbly and dry, almost like an oversweet biscuit. they arent at all inedible, in fact i had a few for breakfast with coffee this morning, and even though i enjoyed them i knew they were wrong, of only in that they failed to live up to my intentions. that’s how i feel about this book

it’s a bold and kinda interesting idea, only as magical as it needs to be, and with a fun enough and intentional use of language. it’s even slow and loose and digressive in a way i like to call a “hangout novel,” one of my favorite things to read right now. the prose, too, is good. it’s just…. the idea at the center is so out of focus, so underbaked…. yeah, my cookies were dry, but i still prepared a dish, put them in the oven, 
tem them cool, and stored them. they were incomplete and yet well made

title: The Master of Go
author: Yasunari Kawabata
content:
- at first i didnt like it -- too stuffy shirt --- but like with JCO
  above, there was a point where i just... got it. its very good
- a great contrast with [[Osamu Dazai - The Setting Sun|The Setting Sun]], too. both novels trace the fall
  of the aristocracy, but this book, like Balzac, mourns its
  passing. Setting Sun takes a more ironical (and modernist!) approach
  to which i'm more sympathetic, but either way its an interesting
  contrast. Naoji might say this book believes in its own lies more
  so than any of those its trying to convince
- lol, just read on wikipedia (looking up his name for this document
  then skimming) that his art movement explicitly stood against
  proletarian art. that's so fitting with point above
- yall, i think this might actually be fascist. its at least
  japanese-supremacist as fuck. theres a chapter about how japan saved
  Go from china that is.... i mean this was written during the war

title: Revenge
author: Yoko Ogawa
review:
[[2024-09-02]]

honest: i was hoping for more. i'm an itinerant hater, moving book to book in search of the smallest thing i can find wrong, and here i just found too many conventional things. i loved the last one i read by her, the housekeeper and the professor, especially how unresolvable it felt, like one hundred thousand things were going on just out a frame. that was my biggest (internal) praise. in this however, these stories, i felt the same way, but where it felt magisterial in the novel, here it seemed only the nature of the form, all short stories require that because of length, so the feeling of mystery i craved was gone. how dare it!

in essence, the point of this review is i'm a baby, perhaps a hamster, craving out a sensation i've felt before. and i didn't get the experience i desired. of course i'm going to read more by this author

review:

God I spent years on this one, with long breaks between. It’s good though, time to time. I think it’s such a tell that the best of Murakamis early translators went so freely with his stuff: it ain’t all there yet.
